posts.cooked:
Hello CD .

I have read lots of posts for this season about how to control elevators and arms.  One approach is with a state machine.  Our 2023 robot used this method and we are going to be using something similar this year.  I took our 2023 code and created a very generic example .

The full example is here: https://github.com/hollisms/GraphCommandExample

The GraphCommand is here: src/main/java/frc/util/GraphCommand

Feel free to clone/fork and use as you like.  You just need to add the GraphCommand.java file into your project, if you choose to use it.

The intent is to create a Subsystem, create a GraphCommand and set it as the default command.  Then use it to send Commands to your other subsystems.  The example lays this out.  Additionally, in the sample project there is a picture of the graph that was created using draw.io .  There is a draw.io plugin for vscode.

Additionally, here is a sample exerpt from our robot so you can see how it might look…

In this sample code the method ArmController.getArmCommand(x,y,z) is a Command factory that configures the 3 degrees of freedom for our arm.  Each is implemented in its own subsystem.  The .andThen() conditions are used to specify when the transition to the state has been achieved.
Not a bad idea, but how is this any diff than using Triggers on other subsystems based off the position of your arm and that subsystem

Philosophically, I think triggers (event-driven architecture) are great for stimulus-response applications. I believe state machines are well-suited for process- or orchestration-based applications. There is a lot of overlap and gray area.

Practically, in my opinion, if you want your mechanism to proceed sequentially through a series of “set points” or “waypoints,” a state machine is better suited.

But largely Tom-A-to, Tom-ahh-to.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: I think @nstrike meant a state machine implemented with triggers such as my two examples. I’ll try out your class soon (team trying to get LL vision to work at the moment):

Thanks I must have missed these examples. You did a much better job of documenting!

It looks like the MooreLikeFSM example approach is… Given I’m in state A, when I get an event (trigger) transition to state B.

GraphCommand approach is…  Given I’m in state A and the next requested state is D, follow the graph that connects A to D and transition through state B and state C (or whatever is defined in the graph) while minimizing transition cost and obeying “one-way” connections.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Thanks - I understand. You are making a most efficient open walk through a weighted graph of states.

I see you are using xxxcommand.schedule() to change states. I believe the recommendation is NOT to schedule a command within a command thus my example of using Triggers to do so. But that wasn’t the relevant part of your project.
Thanks for the feed back.  I’ll think about how to refactor that!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
For something this deep in the implementation layer, direct use of schedule is fine.  The important part is that you use it in a constrained enough way that you don’t end up with lifecycle errors; that’s actually easier to do from inside a generic utility class.

I think the public API here could maybe be cleaner but it’s a cool idea.
